page.title: 01S From the Top Of Dorset
page.content: In an area of outstanding beauty, Dorset's highest point Pilsdon Pen (909ft), and the third highest Lewesdon Hill, overlook the Marshwood vale to the sea. The virtually treeless top of the Pen is grazed by cattle and sheep; the very steep sides are thickly covered in gorse and scrub. The views across the fertile vale to the sea, and over the valley to the tree-covered Lewesdon Hil, and to further flung countes, are very popular with walkers who follow the steep paths to the O.S. triangulation point on Pilsdon Pen. Small family farms predominate, producing mainly milk, with some sheep and beef. Pilsdon Manor, beside the tiny grade 1 church which is awash with wild daffodils in the spring, is now a community for people who have been addicted to alchohol or drugs. There
